@barhoom 's analysis motivated me to do some more research. As an alternative to the GovTrack analysis methodology, I calculated speed of bill passing between different instances (i.e. from proposal to committee to assembly to each of the senate readings) giving it a weight when compared to historical averages. Then calculated percentage of Ayes and Noes in voting for passing each committee instance  and also assigned weight compared to average. I used these weights to project future legislative time for each bill and compared it to remaining legislative times for each state, (deducing 15% for being electoral year). Did some more calculations, including a framework for comparing corporate liquidity (cash on hand) of companies interested in testing against State government S&P ratings, but I don't have the time to explain now.

LOutBelow has made a detailed estimate based of statistics on passage of legislation in the states, and I agree that California have the best chance to be the first state.  However, I have made the observation that the State of South Australia (a less economically active Australian state) has already tabled some legislation allowing experimental AVs, effectively giving them a leg up for any R&D or production opportunities that might emerge in-country (They are also losing out on existing plants which are closing shortly).  Similar efforts could be made from "Rust belt" states who want a free way to get a leg up on investment (They don't need to invest any state budget, just pass legislation), and such a movement with support in the polls could be rushed through quite rapidly.  We are running short on time to pass any such legislation but with 50 states I think the chance is around 65%.

Limiting the focus to those bills already on the agenda, 24% of bills that receive committee hearings are enacted. Five qualifying bills are currently on the table and are going through the committee process, so there is a 75% chance that at least one of these bills should be enacted. I will use 75% as my baseline. The median time for a bill to become law is 215 days, but there are only about 140 days left in the year. These numbers are at the federal level, so I will assume the median time is shorter at the state level since the respective state congresses have slightly less partisan resistance. As others have stated, most states are already finished with the year's legislative sessions so the effective remaining time to enact any of these laws is closer to 30 days. I do not know when each of the bills was first introduced so I will assume they are already on average 40 days old considering where they are in the legislative process. Forecast reduced to 40%. Considering this is election season for many congressman, I do not expect this issue to be at the top of most agendas so that could lower the likelihood of being enacted. Forecast reduced to 35%. There is always the possibility of a bill being introduced in a special session or an amendment added to another bill. While this is unlikely, it can only increase the chances. Forecast increased to 37%. The recent headline-making death of a "driver" of an autonomous vehicle may be polarizing in making politicians hesitant to enact these laws. Forecast reduced to 22%. Since Tesla is at the forefront of this area and its headquarters are located in California, I could see the California legislation having slightly more incentive to pass their bill, even if to just allow testing on public roads. Forecast increased to 27%.

The technology is already in place to make full autonomous operation possible. The biggest hurdles are liability and infrastructure. I know from participation in an autonomous vehicle research group, that these issues have been worked through over the last several years. Some locations already have laws clarifying liability issues, and those existing laws can serve as models for other locations. Restrictions to certain roads partially answers the infrastructure problem, and is more likely to be a solution for the next several years. While manufacturers would like broader road access, municipalities are more likely to move slowly. We are more likely to see city by city approvals, and only wider access upon successful operation. This is definitely the future direction, though roll-out will be cautious.
